message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Sliding Mode Control for Networked Fuzzy Singularly Perturbed Systems Under Weighted Try-Once-Discard Protocol
Paper Abstract: In this article, the sliding mode control issue is investigated for a class of discrete-time Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy networked singularly perturbed systems via an observer-based technique. Moreover, to process the measurement output and schedule the transmission sequence for relieving the communication burden, a logarithmic quantizer and a weighted try-once-discard protocol are synthesized, which can further improve the network bandwidth utilization in networked control systems. Based on the fuzzy observer states, a novel fuzzy sliding surface is established by considering the singularly perturbed parameter properly, and we endeavor to synthesize a sliding mode control law such that the reachability of the prescribed sliding surface could be guaranteed. In addition, by virtue of the convex optimization theory and Lyapunov approach, sufficient conditions are developed to guarantee the asymptotic stability of the sliding mode dynamics as well as the error system with an expected <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_{\infty }$</tex-math></inline-formula> performance. Finally, a verification example is presented to illustrate the feasibility and effectivity of the proposed method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy systems:

## Overview

The Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) model is a precise fuzzy modeling approach focused on accuracy, which contrasts with the Mamdani model that emphasizes interpretability.

## Key Characteristics

The TSK system is similar to Mamdani, but the defuzzification process is included in the execution of the fuzzy rules, and the consequent of the rule is represented through a polynomial function (usually constant or linear).

## Advantages

The main advantage of using TSK over Mamdani is that it is computationally efficient and works well within other algorithms, such as PID control and with optimization algorithms, and it can also guarantee the continuity of the output surface. TSK is usually used within other complex methods, such as in adaptive neuro fuzzy inference systems.

## Applications

An adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) is a kind of artificial neural network that is based on Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy inference system, which demonstrates one of the major modern applications of this approach.

Based on the search results, here's information about Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy systems:

## Overview

The Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) model is a precise fuzzy modeling approach focused on accuracy, which contrasts with the Mamdani model that emphasizes interpretability.

## Key Characteristics

The TSK system is similar to Mamdani, but the defuzzification process is included in the execution of the fuzzy rules, and the consequent of the rule is represented through a polynomial function (usually constant or linear).

## Advantages

The main advantage of using TSK over Mamdani is that it is computationally efficient and works well within other algorithms, such as PID control and with optimization algorithms, and it can also guarantee the continuity of the output surface. TSK is usually used within other complex methods, such as in adaptive neuro fuzzy inference systems.

## Applications

An adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) is a kind of artificial neural network that is based on Takagi–Sugeno fuzzy inference system, which demonstrates one of the major modern applications of this approach.

Web search results for query: "sliding mode control"

Links: [{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Terminal sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Integral sliding mode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_sliding_mode"},{"title":"Talk:Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Predictive control of switching power converters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Predictive_control_of_switching_power_converters"},{"title":"Runner3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Runner3"}]

Here are the search results for **sliding mode control**:

## Overview

Sliding mode control (SMC) is a nonlinear control method that alters the dynamics of a nonlinear system by applying a discontinuous control signal that forces the system to "slide" along a cross-section of the system's normal behavior.

## How It Works

Sliding mode control uses practically infinite gain to force the trajectories of a dynamic system to slide along the restricted sliding mode subspace.(no content)The control law can switch from one continuous structure to another based on the current position in the state space, making sliding mode control a variable structure control method.

## Key Advantages

The main strength of sliding mode control is its robustness, because the control can be as simple as switching between two states (e.g., "on"/"off") and will not be sensitive to parameter variations that enter into the control channel. Additionally, because the control law is not a continuous function, the sliding mode can be reached in finite time.

## Challenges

Real implementations of sliding mode control approximate theoretical behavior with a high-frequency and generally non-deterministic switching control signal that causes the system to "chatter" in a tight neighborhood of the sliding surface.

## Applications

Sliding mode control has many applications in robotics, and has been used for tracking control of unmanned surface vessels in simulated rough seas with high degree of success.

I've performed a web search for "networked control systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.(no content)New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

## Applications and Related Systems

Networked control systems are applied in various domains, including:
- Direct digital control, which takes a centralized network-oriented approach where all instrumentation is gathered by various analog and digital converters which use the network to transport these signals to the central controller, which then follows all of its production rules and causes actions to be sent via the same network to valves, actuators, and other heating, ventilating, and air conditioning components
- Critical infrastructure controlled by interconnected control systems, termed as distributed control systems (DCS) or supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA)

I've completed a web search for "discrete-time systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Fundamentals

A discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities that is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.(no content)In theoretical computer science, a discrete system is a system with a countable number of states.

## Sources of Discrete-Time Signals

Discrete-time signals can usually be classified into one of two groups: by acquiring values of an analog signal at constant or variable rate through a process called sampling, or by observing an inherently discrete-time process, such as the weekly peak value of a particular economic indicator.

## Linear Time-Invariant Systems

A discrete-time linear time-invariant system is defined as one operating in discrete time where sequences are processed using discrete summation rather than an integral.(no content)Almost everything in continuous-time systems has a counterpart in discrete-time systems.

## Applications and Analysis

For a discrete time LTI system, the condition for BIBO (bounded-input, bounded-output) stability is that the impulse response be absolutely summable.(no content)A discrete-time LTI system is causal if the current value of the output depends on only the current value and past values of the input.

Discrete-time systems are fundamental in digital signal processing, control theory, and many engineering applications where systems operate on sampled data.

Links: [{"title":"Discrete time and continuous time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_time_and_continuous_time"},{"title":"Discrete system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_system"},{"title":"Linear time-invariant system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_time-invariant_system"},{"title":"Observability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability_Gramian"},{"title":"Controllability Gramian - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability_Gramian"},{"title":"BIBO stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BIBO_stability"},{"title":"Marginal stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marginal_stability"},{"title":"DEVS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DEVS"},{"title":"Stochastic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_process"},{"title":"Continuous simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_simulation"}]

I've completed a web search for "discrete-time systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Fundamentals

A discrete-time signal is a time series consisting of a sequence of quantities that is not a function of a continuous argument; however, it may have been obtained by sampling from a continuous-time signal.(no content)In theoretical computer science, a discrete system is a system with a countable number of states.

## Sources of Discrete-Time Signals

Discrete-time signals can usually be classified into one of two groups: by acquiring values of an analog signal at constant or variable rate through a process called sampling, or by observing an inherently discrete-time process, such as the weekly peak value of a particular economic indicator.

## Linear Time-Invariant Systems

A discrete-time linear time-invariant system is defined as one operating in discrete time where sequences are processed using discrete summation rather than an integral.(no content)Almost everything in continuous-time systems has a counterpart in discrete-time systems.

## Applications and Analysis

For a discrete time LTI system, the condition for BIBO (bounded-input, bounded-output) stability is that the impulse response be absolutely summable.(no content)A discrete-time LTI system is causal if the current value of the output depends on only the current value and past values of the input.

Discrete-time systems are fundamental in digital signal processing, control theory, and many engineering applications where systems operate on sampled data.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

## Lyapunov Stability

Here's what I found about Lyapunov stability:

### Definition and Core Concepts

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means solutions that start close enough also eventually converge to the equilibrium.(no content)Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.

### Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

### Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Applications

The "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)The concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "H-infinity control"

Links: [{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"H-infinity loop-shaping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_loop-shaping"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Talk:H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:H%E2%88%9E"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Rosenbrock system matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosenbrock_system_matrix"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Infinite H - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_H"},{"title":"L'Hôpital's rule - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L'H%C3%B4pital's_rule"},{"title":"Infinite switch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_switch"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of H-infinity control:

## What is H-infinity Control?

H-infinity methods are used in control theory to synthesize controllers to achieve stabilization with guaranteed performance.(no content)A control designer expresses the control problem as a mathematical optimization problem and then finds the controller that solves this optimization.

## Key Characteristics

H∞ techniques have the advantage over classical control techniques in that they are readily applicable to problems involving multivariate systems with cross-coupling between channels; disadvantages include the level of mathematical understanding needed to apply them successfully and the need for a reasonably good model of the system to be controlled.

## Mathematical Basis

H∞ control comes from the name of the mathematical space over which the optimization takes place: H∞ is the Hardy space of matrix-valued functions that are analytic and bounded in the open right-half of the complex plane.(no content)For a matrix-valued function, the norm can be interpreted as a maximum gain in any direction and at any frequency; for SISO systems, this is effectively the maximum magnitude of the frequency response.

## Applications

The term robust control became almost synonymous with the term H-infinity control, since it was the techniques in the development of the latter that gave the early impetus for new methods. A notable application is H∞ loop-shaping, which allows the control designer to apply classical loop-shaping concepts to the multivariable frequency response to get good robust performance.

Links: [{"title":"Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Talk:Quantization (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quantization_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Digital signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_processing"},{"title":"Digital signal (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Processing"},{"title":"Signal-to-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_to_noise_ratio_(image_processing)"},{"title":"Signal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Signal-to-quantization-noise ratio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal-to-quantization-noise_ratio"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of quantization in signal processing:

## Definition

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

## Role in Analog-to-Digital Conversion

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.

## Common Implementations

Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

## Quantization Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.

## Dithering to Reduce Distortion

In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of quantization in signal processing:

## Definition

Quantization is the process of mapping input values from a large set (often a continuous set) to output values in a (countable) smaller set, often with a finite number of elements.(no content)Rounding and truncation are typical examples of quantization processes.

## Role in Analog-to-Digital Conversion

An analog-to-digital converter (ADC) can be modeled as two processes: sampling and quantization. Sampling converts a time-varying voltage signal into a discrete-time signal, a sequence of real numbers. Quantization replaces each real number with an approximation from a finite set of discrete values.

## Common Implementations

Common word lengths are 8-bit (256 levels), 16-bit (65,536 levels) and 24-bit (16.8 million levels).

## Quantization Noise

Quantizing a sequence of numbers produces a sequence of quantization errors which is sometimes modeled as an additive random signal called quantization noise because of its stochastic behavior.(no content)The more levels a quantizer uses, the lower is its quantization noise power.

## Dithering to Reduce Distortion

In order to make the quantization error independent of the input signal, the signal is dithered by adding noise to the signal. This slightly reduces signal-to-noise ratio, but can completely eliminate the distortion.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about observer-based control:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Purpose and Importance

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback. In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

## Applications in Control Design

In complicated systems, all system states are not in general measured and so observers must be included and incorporated in pole placement design. Observer-based control is particularly valuable when not all states of a system are directly measurable but are needed for effective feedback control.

## Observer Types

Several types of observers exist for different control scenarios, including:
- Nonlinear high-gain observer methods that converge quickly without the peaking phenomenon, such as sliding mode control which can be used to design an observer that brings one estimated state's error to zero in finite time.
- Multi-observer structures with multiple high-gain observers working simultaneously, where the first layer consists of multiple observers with different estimation states, and the second layer determines the importance weights.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "singularly perturbed systems"

Links: [{"title":"Singular perturbation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_perturbation"},{"title":"Method of matched asymptotic expansions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Method_of_matched_asymptotic_expansions"},{"title":"Perturbation theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory"},{"title":"Oleksandr Boichuk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boichuk,_Alexander"},{"title":"Perturbation theory (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_theory_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Singular value decomposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_value_decomposition"},{"title":"Perturbation (astronomy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_(astronomy)"},{"title":"Singularity (systems theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singularity_(system_theory)"},{"title":"Eigenvalue perturbation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenvalue_perturbation"},{"title":"Perturbation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation"}]

## Singularly Perturbed Systems

Based on the search results, here's an overview of singularly perturbed systems:

### Definition

A singular perturbation problem is a problem containing a small parameter that cannot be approximated by setting the parameter value to zero.(no content)This is in contrast to regular perturbation problems, for which a uniform approximation of this form can be obtained.

### Key Characteristics

Singularly perturbed problems are generally characterized by dynamics operating on multiple scales.(no content)A singular perturbation generally occurs when a problem's small parameter multiplies its highest operator. Thus naively taking the parameter to be zero changes the very nature of the problem. In the case of differential equations, boundary conditions cannot be satisfied; in algebraic equations, the possible number of solutions is decreased.

### Practical Applications

An electrically driven robot manipulator can have slower mechanical dynamics and faster electrical dynamics, thus exhibiting two time scales. In such cases, we can divide the system into two subsystems, one corresponding to faster dynamics and other corresponding to slower dynamics, and then design controllers for each one of them separately.

Another application involves reaction–diffusion systems in which one reagent diffuses much more slowly than another, which can form spatial patterns marked by areas where a reagent exists, and areas where it does not, with sharp transitions between them.

### Solution Methods

The method of matched asymptotic expansions is a common approach to finding an accurate approximation to the solution to an equation, or system of equations. It is particularly used when solving singularly perturbed differential equations.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json to add all triples

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors and rerunning validation

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Observer-Based Sliding Mode Control for Networked Fuzzy Singularly Perturbed Systems Under Weighted Try-Once-Discard Protocol". Here are the results:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes novel methods for sliding mode control synthesis and a fuzzy observer-based design approach.

**Extracted Triples (9 total):**

1. **Sliding mode control** (method) - `proposes` - Novel control law design
2. **Fuzzy logic** (concept) - `uses` - Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy system modeling
3. **Singular perturbation** (concept) - `uses` - Addresses singularly perturbed system dynamics
4. **Networked control system** (task) - `uses` - Control problem in communication-constrained environments
5. **State observer** (method) - `uses` - Estimates system states from outputs
6. **Quantization (signal processing)** (method) - `proposes` - Logarithmic quantizer for measurement processing
7. **Lyapunov stability** (concept) - `uses` - Stability analysis methodology
8. **H-infinity methods in control theory** (concept) - `uses` - Performance guarantee framework
9. **Discrete time and continuous time** (concept) - `uses` - Addresses discrete-time system formulation

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Sliding mode control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control)
- [Fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)
- [Singular perturbation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singular_perturbation)
- [Networked control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system)
- [State observer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer)

- [Discrete time and continuous time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_time_and_continuous_time)
